Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental Investigation of Magmatic Processes at Volcan Quizapu
Award.AbstractNarration:
Volcanic eruptions taking place along subduction zones (arcs) are commonly interpreted as triggered by the influx of new magma to their shallow storage systems. This project aims to explore the late-stage changes in temperature, pressure, water content, and composition of arc magmas on the "crystal cargo" they carry, by testing the premise that the textures and compositions of erupted materials preserve this chronology. Comparison of experimental and natural samples will shed light on magma chamber and transit processes occurring between magma mixing and eruption.

Two historical eruptions of Volcan Quizapu (Chilean Andes), one effusive and one explosive, have been characterized petrologically and geochemically in prior studies. Evidence points to a magmatic system of predominantly dacite with single-episode, eruption-triggering influxes of andesitic magma. The relative simplicity of these interactions makes Quizapu an ideal starting point for a targeted experimental study addressing questions related to magma mixing and ascent/eruption. Key lines of inquiry include constraining resorption/de-stabilization kinetics of plagioclase and amphibole in response to perturbation, as these minerals preserve evidence of magma storage conditions prior to eruption. The goals of this investigation are to (1) establish pre-eruption environmental conditions of Quizapu dacite and andesite, (2) examine response times of key thermobarometers and hygrometers through a series of step-heating experiments, (3) explore the formation conditions of sieve-textured plagioclase, and (4) broadly examine crystal-scale responses to thermodynamic perturbations through high-resolution chemical analysis and diffusion modeling. The results will have general implications for magma mixing processes among intermediate-composition arc magmas, not only because the recharge-triggered Quizapu events are typical of arc volcanoes, but also because the crystal-scale processes on which the study focuses (the influence of halogens on amphibole composition and stability, plagioclase dissolution kinetics upon heating, and formation of sieve-texture via several proposed mechanisms) are germane to a broad spectrum of magmatic settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Eruptions at arc volcanoes are commonly interpreted as triggered by the influx of new magma to their shallow storage systems.  Two historical eruptions of Volcan Quizapu (Chilean Andes), one effusive and one explosive, have been characterized petrologically and geochemically, with evidence pointing to a magmatic system of one type of magma (dacite) punctuated by single-episode, eruption-triggering influxes of a hotter magma (andestite).  The relative simplicity of the interaction made Quizapu an ideal starting point for targeted experimental studies addressing the timing and implications of magma mixing. 

Main project (1). We examined the assertion that the styles of eruptions were strongly influenced by magma mixing through a course of laboratory experiments on the dacite. A suite of water-saturated phase equilibrium experiments ranging from 800- 900 °C and 35-200 MPa were performed using isochemical 1932 pumice and 1846-7 lava samples. Our experiments tightly constrain the combination of temperature, pressure, and other environmental conditions at which the magma was stored prior to eruption. The main phase assemblage is stable at 850 ± 10 °C and 4.5-5 km depth, corresponding to ~125 MPa water pressure. The tight pressure constraint necessitates a laterally extensive reservoir that is unrealistically thin. To more plausibly accommodate the 4-5 km3 of material expelled during each eruption, we suggest that the Quizapu dacite magma was slightly water undersaturated during equilibration. Additionally, our experiments and observations reveal inconsistencies in the prevailing explanation for the effusive nature of the 1846-7 eruption. We suggest that volatile distribution, conduit geometry, and ascent processes contributed to the effusive nature of the 1846-7 eruption.

Main project (2). Diffusion of Mg in plagioclase is a promising magma mixing chronometer, but it is hampered by the fact that published values of the diffusion coefficient, D, vary by 5 orders of magnitude. We performed novel experiments aimed at assessing D under hydrous conditions relevant to the magmatic systems underlying arc volcanoes such as Quizapu. The combined effects of H2O-saturation, elevated pressure, and magmatic fO2 on D at 900 ºC and 125 MPa were investigated. Our analysis of sectioned crystals reveals that diffusivities are anisotropic and up to ~100 times larger than any previously reported. The presence of substantial H2O, good interfacial contact with liquid surroundings, and phase instability (dissolution), may enhance Mg diffusion in our experiment. Our work underscores the importance of examining diffusion in all directions, not just those along crystallographic axes (figure attached).

Overall, the results of these two main projects have general implications for magma mixing processes among intermediate-composition arc magmas, not only because the recharge-triggered Quizapu events are typical of arc volcanoes, but also because the crystal-scale processes on which the study focuses are germane to a broad spectrum of magmatic settings.

 

Broader Impacts

The project supported the training and mentoring of four female students. Two undergraduate students received training in the design and execution of an experimental program of study and were mentored through the process of presenting research results to an audience and applying to graduate school. T. Leonhardi received her BS in 2015 and is currently a second-year graduate student in a strong geoscience department. D. Tachera, a Hawaiian student, is a second-year graduate student in our department. An international graduate student, C. Pineda, performed experiments in the laboratory during the summer of 2016 and presented research findings at two international conferences. E. First, graduate student supported, trained and mentored under the aegis of this award, received her PhD in 2017 and has moved to a postdoctoral position in a strong geoscience department.   

Teachers and educators of middle schoolers were provided professional development skills in the form of hands-on workshops in geoscience given by J. Hammer.
